div1.p: This program advertises the "Theatre Guild On the Air" production of “Yellow Jack” sponsored by United States Steel.

div1.head: Program: Yellow Jack, January 20, 1946

UNITED STATES STEEL

ThE

__________________________________________________
“Yellow Jack”
__________________________________________________
Program for
January 20, 1946
____________________________________________
Sunday Evenings Over WJZ and Stations of the
AMERICAN BROADCASTING COMPANY
div1.p:
UNITED STATES STEEL CORPORATION
welcomes you to
THE THEATRE GUILD ON THE AIR
production of
“YELLOW JACK”
by SIDNEY HOWARD and PAUL de KRUIF
with
WALTER
ABEL
ALAN
BAXTER
LUTHER
ADLER

Director
HOMER FICKETT

Producer
GEORGE KONDOLF

Musical Director
HAROLD LEVEY

Radio Adapter
ARTHUR ARENT
ARMINA MARSHALL, Executive Director
General Supervision by THERESA HELBURN and LAWRENCE LANGNER
Introducing the Play and Players, LAWRENCE LANGNER
GEORGE HICKS, reporting for U. S. Steel.
Announcer, NORMAN BROKENSHIRE.
BEHIND THE SCENES IN TONIGHT'S PLAY

WALTER ABEL has been dubbed by
Paramount Pictures the “Prince of
Versatility”-- and rightly so. There is no
such thing as typing this unpredicticable
actor; you will always find him in a new
role which seems tailor-made. This is a
far cry from how the experts previously
labeled him--“one of those serious O'Neill
Players,” and “a swell district attorney
type.”

Landing in New York in 1916, he
studied the drama at the American Acad-
emy of Dramatic Arts. Two years later,
on the eve of his graduation, he appeared
in an Academy play at the old Lyceum
Theatre. Henry Miller, the producer,
was in the audience and gave him a con-
tract to appear in the road company of
“Come Out of the Kitchen” at a “fabu-
lous” salary of $60 per week.

The following five years found Abel in
many Broadway productions.

In 1924-25, he appeared in Province-
town Playhouse productions. Thereafter,
he played very serious roles and subse-
quently became identified as a dramatic
actor, although he originally scored as a
comedian. However, this was overcome
when Chester Erskine, producer, gave
him a chance in the top spot of the stage
play, “I Love an Actor.” It was a hit for
Abel. Then came “When Ladies Meet,”
which was followed by adventures in and
with motion pictures.

He was signed by Paramount in Octo-
ber, 1932, and made his first big Holly-
wood splash in “The Three Musketeers.”
Since that time, he has divided his tal-
ents between Broadway and Hollywood.
Among his more recent pictures is “An
American Romance,” partially filmed at
U. S. Steel plants out in Chicago and
Gary, Indiana, and the great Mesabi iron
ore range in northern Minnesota.

ALAN BAXTER, one of cinema's fa-
mous tough guys, is a graduate of
Williams College. He also attended
George Pierce Baker's School of Drama
at Yale. After serving with the Group
Theatre for three years, he appeared in
the Theatre Union's “The Black Pit.”
This brought him a contract with Wal-
ter Wanger. As a free-lance actor in
Hollywood, he has appeared in 45 mo-
tion pictures. Two and a half years ago
he donned khaki when he enlisted in the
Army Air Corps. While in the service, he
appeared in “Winged Victory.” Some of
his Hollywood efforts have included
“Abe Lincoln in Illinois,” “Saboteur,” and
“The Trail of the Lonesome Pine.”

LUTHER ADLER served his appren-
ticeship in the theatre with his fa-
mous father, the late Jacob T. Adler. As
one of the original Provincetown Players,
he made long tours through the United
States, England, and North Africa. In
1929, he joined The Theatre Guild and
appeared in many of its productions.

He has also been under the manage-
ment of William A. Brady, Sam H. Har-
ris, and Guthrie McClintic.

Theatre-goers remember him well as
the violinist prize-fighter in “Golden Boy”
and the power-mad business genius in
“Success Story.”

Currently, Adler is appearing on
Broadway in “Dunnigan's Daughter.”

THIS LABEL IS
YOUR GUIDE TO
GOOD STEEL

The sure, easy way to be certain of
getting quality steel in any article
you buy is to look for the U·S·S
Label. This label on the article tells
you it is made with steel backed by
all the engineering skill and manu-
facturing knowledge of the world's
foremost steel makers.

MANUFACTURED FROM
USS
STEEL
UNITED STATES STEEL
NEXT WEEK:

“THE FRONT PAGE,” starring Melvyn Douglas and
Michael O'Shea. A rapid-fire comedy melodrama
about the life of a newspaper reporter, written by
Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur.
